This bit allows for lower power consumption in wait mode
This read-only flag indicates whether the MSCAN is synchronized to the CAN bus
Enables an internal 16-bit wide free running timer which is clocked by the bit clock rate
Allows the MSCAN to restart from sleep mode or from power down mode when traffic detected on CAN
This bit requests the MSCAN to enter sleep mode

When this bit is set by the CPU, the MSCAN skips to initialization mode.\n Any ongoing transmission or reception is aborted and synchronization to the CAN bus is lost.\n The module indicates entry to initialization mode by setting INITAK = 1
Module enable
This bit defines the clock source for the MSCAN module
Allows the MSCAN to perform an internal loopback test
This bit configures the MSCAN as a CAN bus monitor
This bit configures the bus-off state recovery mode of the MSCAN\n See Bosch CAN 2.0A/B protocol specification

If WUPE in CANCTL0 is enabled, this bit defines whether the integrated low-pass filter is\n applied to protect the MSCAN from spurious wakeup\n If enabled, MSCAN wakes only on a dominant pulse on the CAN bus of length Twup
This flag indicates whether the MSCAN module has entered sleep mode

This flag indicates whether the MSCAN module is in initialization mode.
 It is used as a handshake flag for the INITRQ initialization mode request.
 Initialization mode is active when INITRQ = 1 and INITAK = 1.
 The registers CANCTL1, CANBTR0, CANBTR1, CANIDAC, CANIDAR0-CANIDAR7, and CANIDMR0-CANIDMR7 can
 be written only by the CPU when the MSCAN is in initialization mode

title.description: Bus Timing Register 0\n This register configures various CAN bus timing parameters

choiceOption.toolTip: The synchronization jump width defines the maximum number of time quanta (Tq) clock cycles a bit can\n be shortened or lengthened to achieve resynchronization to data transitions on the CAN bus

intOption.toolTip: These bits determine the time quanta (Tq) clock which is used to build up the bit timing.\n Prescale = N+1

title.description: Bus Timing Register 1\n This register configures various CAN bus timing parameters of the MSCAN module

binaryOption.toolTip: This bit determines the number of CAN bus samples taken per bit time,\n For 3 samples, PHASE_SEG1 must be at least 2 time quanta (Tq)

choiceOption.toolTip:
Time segments within the bit time fix the number of clock cycles per bit time and the location of the sample point.
 Time = N+1
 The bit time is determined by the oscillator frequency, the baud rate prescaler, and the number of time quanta (Tq) clock cycles per bit.
 Bit time = (1 + timesegment1 + timesegment2) * (Prescaler value)/ fCANCLK
Time segments within the bit time fix the number of clock cycles per bit time and the location of the sample point.

binaryOption.toolTip: If the MSCAN detects CAN bus activity while in sleep mode and CANTCTL0[WUPE] = 1, the module will\n set WUPIF. If not masked, a wake-up interrupt is pending while this flag is set
This flag is set when the MSCAN changes its current CAN bus status due to the actual value of the\n transmit error counter (TEC) and the receive error counter (REC)

choiceOption.toolTip: The values of the error counters control the actual CAN bus status of the MSCAN
The values of the error counters control the actual CAN bus status of the MSCAN

binaryOption.toolTip: This flag is set when a data overrun condition occurs. If not masked, an error interrupt is pending while this flag is set
RXF is set by the MSCAN when a new message is shifted in the receiver FIFO

title.description: Receiver Interrupt Enable Register\n This register contains the interrupt enable bits for the interrupt flags described in the\n CANRFLG register

binaryOption.toolTip: WUPIE and WUPE must both be enabled if the recovery mechanism from stop or wait is required

choiceOption.toolTip: These RSTAT enable bits control the sensitivity level in which receiver state changes are causing CSCIF interrupts
These TSTAT enable bits control the sensitivity level in which transmitter state changes are causing CSCIF interrupts

binaryOption.toolTip: These flags indicates that the associated transmit message buffer is empty, and thus not scheduled for transmission

title.description: Transmitter Interrupt Enable Register\n This register contains the interrupt enable bits for the transmit buffer empty interrupt flags
Transmitter Message Abort Request Register\n The CANTARQ register allows abort request of queued messages

binaryOption.toolTip: The CPU sets the ABTRQx bit to request that a scheduled message buffer (TXEx = 0) be aborted

title.description: Transmitter Message Abort Acknowledge Register\n The CANTAAK register indicates the successful abort of a queued message, if requested by the appropriate bits in the CANTARQ register

binaryOption.toolTip: This flag acknowledges that a message was aborted due to a pending abort request from the CPU

title.description: Transmit Buffer Selection Register\n The CANTBSEL register allows the selection of the actual transmit message buffer,\n which then will be accessible in the CANTXFG register space

choiceOption.toolTip: The lowest numbered bit places the respective transmit buffer in the CANTXFG register space (e.g., TX1 = 1\n and TX0 = 1 selects transmit buffer TX0; TX1 = 1 and TX0 = 0 selects transmit buffer TX1)

title.description: Identifier Acceptance Control Register\n The CANIDAC register is used for identifier acceptance control

choiceOption.toolTip: The CPU sets these flags to define the identifier acceptance filter organization. In filter closed mode, no\n message is accepted such that the foreground buffer is never reloaded

The MSCAN sets these flags to indicate an identifier acceptance hit.\n The IDHIT indicators are always related to the message in the foreground buffer (RxFG).\n When a message gets shifted into the foreground buffer of the receiver FIFO the indicators are updated as well

binaryOption.toolTip: If BORM is set in MSCAN Control Register 1 (CANCTL1), this bit indicates whether the module has\n entered the bus-off state. Clearing this bit requests the recovery from bus-off
binaryOption.description: Bus-off State Hold Until User Request

title.description: Receive Data Length Register\n This register keeps the data length field of the CAN frame

choiceOption.toolTip: The data length code contains the number of bytes (data byte count) of the respective message. During\n the transmission of a remote frame, the data length code is transmitted as programmed while the number\n of transmitted data bytes is always 0. The data byte count ranges from 0 to 8 for a data frame
